title: Remembering Bud Cort: The Legacy of Harold and Maude Star
summary: Bud Cort, an American actor renowned for his role in the 1971 cult classic Harold and Maude, has died at age 77 after a prolonged illness. His friend Dorian Hannaway confirmed the news, highlighting Cort's extensive career spanning over 80 films and TV series, including notable works like The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou. Cort's portrayal of Harold, a death-obsessed young man who falls in love with an elderly woman named Maude, became iconic, despite the film's initial commercial failure. Over time, Harold and Maude gained a loyal cult following due to its dark humor and unique romantic storyline, with director Edgar Wright praising Cort's performance as one of the greatest in film history. Born in New Rochelle, New York, in 1948, Cort developed an early passion for acting, sneaking into Broadway shows and later moving to Los Angeles to pursue film. He started with small roles in movies like M*A*S*H and Brewster McCloud before achieving fame. Throughout his five-decade career, Cort appeared in diverse projects such as Heat, Dogma, and TV series like Arrested Development, earning nominations for Golden Globe and Bafta awards. His death marks the end of an era for fans who cherished his contributions to cinema.

background_read: Bud Cort was born in 1948 in New Rochelle, New York, and showed an early affinity for performing arts, often attending Broadway shows in Manhattan. He moved to Los Angeles in the 1960s to break into the film industry, starting with minor roles before landing significant parts. His breakthrough came with Harold and Maude in 1971, a film that, despite initial poor reception, evolved into a cult classic due to its unconventional themes and Cort's compelling performance. Over his 50-year career, Cort worked with renowned directors like Wes Anderson and Robert Altman, appearing in a variety of genres from comedies to dramas. His death at 77 reflects the end of a prolific era in Hollywood, with tributes highlighting his impact on cinema and his enduring legacy among fans and peers.
